alicloud-datasource-images.body:
data "alicloud_images" "$1" {
    # name_regex - (Optional) A regex string to apply to the image list returned by Alicloud.
    name_regex = ""

    # most_recent - (Optional) If more than one result is returned, use the most recent image.
    most_recent = ""

    # owners - (Optional) Limit search to specific image owners. Valid items are `system`, `self`, `others`, `marketplace`.
    owners = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - ID of the image.
    # "architecture" - Platform type of the image system:i386 | x86_64.
    # "creation_time" - Time of creation.
    # "description" - Description of the image.
    # "image_owner_alias" - Alias of the image owner.
    # "os_name" - Display name of the OS.
    # "status" - Status of the image, with possible values: "UnAvailable", "Available", "Creating" or "CreateFailed".
    # "size" - Size of the image.
    # "disk_device_mappings" - Description of the system with disks and snapshots under an image.
    # "device" - Device information of the created disk: such as /dev/xvdb.
    # "size" - Size of the created disk.
    # "snapshot_id" - Snapshot ID.
    # "product_code" - Product code of the image on the image market.
    # "is_subscribed" - Whether the user has subscribed to the terms of service for the image product corresponding to the ProductCode.
    # "image_version" - Version of the image.
    # "progress" - Progress of image creation, presented in percentages.
}
alicloud-datasource-images.description: The Images data source list image resource list contains private images of the user and images of system resources provided by Alicloud, as well as other public images and those available on the image market.

alicloud-datasource-instance-types.body:
data "alicloud_instance_types" "$1" {
    # cpu_core_count - (Optional) Limit search to specific cpu core count.
    cpu_core_count = ""

    # memory_size - (Optional) Limit search to specific memory size.
    memory_size = ""

    # instance_type_family - (Optional) Allows to filter list of Instance Types based on their
    instance_type_family = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - ID of the instance type.
    # "cpu_core_count" - Number of CPU cores.
    # "memory_size" - Size of memory, measured in GB.
    # "family" - The instance type family.
}
alicloud-datasource-instance-types.description: The Instance Types data source list the ecs_instance_types of Alicloud.

alicloud-datasource-regions.body:
data "alicloud_regions" "$1" {
    # name - (Optional) The full name of the region to select.
    name = ""

    # current - (Optional) Set to true to match only the region configured in the provider.
    current = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - ID of the region.
    # "local_name" - Name of the region in the local language.
}
alicloud-datasource-regions.description: The Regions data source allows access to the list of Alicloud Regions.

alicloud-datasource-zones.body:
data "alicloud_zones" "$1" {
    # available_instance_type - (Optional) Limit search to specific instance type.
    available_instance_type = ""

    # available_resource_creation - (Optional) Limit search to specific resource type. The following values are allowed `Instance`, `Disk` and `VSwitch`.
    available_resource_creation = ""

    # available_disk_category - (Optional) Limit search to specific disk category. Can be either `cloud`, `ephemeral`, or `ephemeral_ssd`.
    available_disk_category = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - ID of the zone.
    # "local_name" - Name of the zone in the local language.
    # "available_instance_types" - Instance types allowed.
    # "available_resource_creation" - Type of resource that can be created.
    # "available_disk_categories" - Set of supported disk categories.
}
alicloud-datasource-zones.description: The Zones data source allows access to the list of Alicloud Zones which can be accessed by an Alicloud account within the region configured in the provider.

alicloud-resource-db-instance.body:
resource "alicloud_db_instance" "$1" {
    # db_instance_storage - (Required) User-defined storage space. Value range: 
    db_instance_storage = ""

    # db_instance_class - (Required) Instance type. For details, see [Instance type table](https://intl.aliyun.com/help/doc-detail/26312.htm?spm=a3c0i.o26228en.a3.2.bRUHF3).
    db_instance_class = ""

    # engine_version - (Required) Database version. Value options: 
    engine_version = ""

    # engine - (Required) Database type. Value options: MySQL, SQLServer, PostgreSQL, and PPAS.
    engine = ""

    # instance_charge_type - (Optional) Valid values are `Prepaid`, `Postpaid`, The default is `Postpaid`.
    instance_charge_type = ""

    # period - (Optional) The time that you have bought the resource, in month. Only valid when instance_charge_type is set as `PrePaid`. Value range [1, 12].
    period = ""

    # zone_id - (Optional) Selected zone to create database instance. You cannot set the ZoneId parameter if the MultiAZ parameter is set to true.
    zone_id = ""

    # multi_az - (Optional) Specifies if the database instance is a multiple Availability Zone deployment.
    multi_az = ""

    # db_instance_net_type - (Optional) Network connection type of an instance. Internet: public network; Intranet: private network
    db_instance_net_type = ""

    # allocate_public_connection - (Optional) If set to true will applies for an Internet connection string of an instance.
    allocate_public_connection = ""

    # instance_network_type - (Optional) VPC: VPC instance; Classic: classic instance. If no value is specified, a classic instance will be created by default.
    instance_network_type = ""

    # vswitch_id - (Optional) The virtual switch ID to launch in VPC. If you want to create instances in VPC network, this parameter must be set.
    vswitch_id = ""

    # master_user_name - (Optional) The master user name for the database instance. Operation account requiring a uniqueness check. It may consist of lower case letters, numbers and underlines, and must start with a letter and have no more than 16 characters.
    master_user_name = ""

    # master_user_password - (Optional) The master password for the database instance. Operation password. It may consist of letters, digits, or underlines, with a length of 6 to 32 characters.
    master_user_password = ""

    # preferred_backup_period - (Optional) Backup period. Values: Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, Saturday, and Sunday.
    preferred_backup_period = ""

    # preferred_backup_time - (Optional) Backup time, in the format ofHH:mmZ- HH:mm Z.
    preferred_backup_time = ""

    # backup_retention_period - (Optional) Retention days of the backup (7 to 730 days). The default value is 7 days.
    backup_retention_period = ""

    # security_ips - (Optional) List of IP addresses under the IP address white list array. The list contains up to 1,000 IP addresses, separated by commas. Supported formats include 0.0.0.0/0, 10.23.12.24 (IP), and 10.23.12.24/24 (Classless Inter-Domain Routing (CIDR) mode. /24 represents the length of the prefix in an IP address. The range of the prefix length is [1,32]).
    security_ips = ""

    # db_mappings - (Optional) Database mappings to attach to db instance. See [Block database](#block-database) below for details.
    db_mappings = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The RDS instance ID.
    # "instance_charge_type" - The instance charge type.
    # "period" - The time that you have bought the resource.
    # "engine" - Database type.
    # "engine_version" - The database engine version.
    # "db_instance_class" - The RDS instance class.
    # "db_instance_storage" - The amount of allocated storage.
    # "port" - The database port.
    # "zone_id" - The zone ID of the DB instance.
    # "db_instance_net_type" - Network connection type of an instance, "Internet" or "Intranet".
    # "instance_network_type" - The instance network type and it has two values: "vpc" and "classic".
    # "db_mappings" - Database mappings attached to db instance.
    # "preferred_backup_period" - Backup period.
    # "preferred_backup_time" - Backup time.
    # "backup_retention_period" - Retention days of the backup.
    # "security_ips" - Security ips of instance whitelist.
    # "connections" - Views all the connection information of a specified instance.
}
alicloud-resource-db-instance.description:
Provides an RDS instance resource.  A DB instance is an isolated database
environment in the cloud.  A DB instance can contain multiple user-created
databases.

alicloud-resource-disk.body:
resource "alicloud_disk" "$1" {
    # size - (Required) The size of the disk in GiBs, and its value depends on `Category`. `cloud` disk value range: 5GB ~ 2000GB and other category disk value range: 20 ~ 32768.
    size = ""

    # availability_zone - (Optional) (Required, Forces new resource) The Zone to create the disk in.
    availability_zone = ""

    # name - (Optional) Name of the ECS disk. This name can have a string of 2 to 128 characters, must contain only alphanumeric characters or hyphens, such as "-",".","_", and must not begin or end with a hyphen, and must not begin with http:// or https://. Default value is null.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) Description of the disk. This description can have a string of 2 to 256 characters, It cannot begin with http:// or https://. Default value is null.
    description = ""

    # category - (Optional) (Optional, Forces new resource) Category of the disk. Valid values are `cloud`, `cloud_efficiency` and `cloud_ssd`. Default is `cloud`.
    category = ""

    # snapshot_id - (Optional) A snapshot to base the disk off of. If it is specified, `size` will be invalid and the disk size is equals to the snapshot size.
    snapshot_id = ""

    # tags - (Optional) A mapping of tags to assign to the resource.
    tags = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The disk ID.
    # "availability_zone" - The Zone to create the disk in.
    # "name" - The disk name.
    # "description" - The disk description.
    # "status" - The disk status.
    # "category" - The disk category.
    # "size" - The disk size.
    # "snapshot_id" - The disk snapshot ID.
    # "tags" - The disk tags.
}
alicloud-resource-disk.description: Provides a ECS disk resource. ~> **NOTE:** One of `size` or `snapshot_id` is required when specifying an ECS disk. If all of them be specified, `size` must more than the size of snapshot which `snapshot_id` represents. Currently, `alicloud_disk` doesn't resize disk.

alicloud-resource-disk-attachment.body:
resource "alicloud_disk_attachment" "$1" {
    # instance_id - (Optional) (Required, Forces new resource) ID of the Instance to attach to.
    instance_id = ""

    # disk_id - (Optional) (Required, Forces new resource) ID of the Disk to be attached.
    disk_id = ""

    # device_name - (Optional) (Required, Forces new resource) The device name to expose to the instance (for example, /dev/xvdb).
    device_name = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "instance_id" - ID of the Instance.
    # "disk_id" - ID of the Disk.
    # "device_name" - The device name exposed to the instance.
}
alicloud-resource-disk-attachment.description: Provides an Alicloud ECS Disk Attachment as a resource, to attach and detach disks from ECS Instances.

alicloud-resource-eip.body:
resource "alicloud_eip" "$1" {
    # bandwidth - (Optional) Maximum bandwidth to the elastic public network, measured in Mbps (Mega bit per second). If this value is not specified, then automatically sets it to 5 Mbps.
    bandwidth = ""

    # internet_charge_type - (Optional) (Optional, Forces new resource) Internet charge type of the EIP, Valid values are `PayByBandwidth`, `PayByTraffic`. Default is `PayByBandwidth`.
    internet_charge_type = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The EIP ID.
    # "bandwidth" - The elastic public network bandwidth.
    # "internet_charge_type" - The EIP internet charge type.
    # "status" - The EIP current status.
    # "ip_address" - The elastic ip address
    # "instance" - The ID of the instance which is associated with the EIP.
}

alicloud-resource-eip-association.body:
resource "alicloud_eip_association" "$1" {
    # allocation_id - (Optional) (Optional, Forces new resource) The allocation EIP ID.
    allocation_id = ""

    # instance_id - (Optional) (Optional, Forces new resource) The ID of the instance.
    instance_id = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "allocation_id" - As above.
    # "instance_id" - As above.
}
alicloud-resource-eip-association.description:
Provides an Alicloud EIP Association resource, to associate and disassociate Elastic IPs from ECS Instances. ~> **NOTE:** `alicloud_eip_association` is useful in scenarios where EIPs are either
 pre-existing or distributed to customers or users and therefore cannot be changed.
 In addition, it only supports ECS-VPC.

alicloud-resource-ess-scaling-configurat.body:
resource "alicloud_ess_scaling_configuration" "$1" {
    # security_group_id - (Required) ID of the security group to which a newly created instance belongs.
    security_group_id = ""

    # io_optimized - (Required) Valid values are `none`, `optimized`, If `optimized`, the launched ECS instance will be I/O optimized.
    io_optimized = ""

    # instance_type - (Required) Resource type of an ECS instance.
    instance_type = ""

    # image_id - (Required) ID of an image file, indicating the image resource selected when an instance is enabled.
    image_id = ""

    # scaling_group_id - (Required) ID of the scaling group of a scaling configuration.
    scaling_group_id = ""

    # scaling_configuration_name - (Optional) Name shown for the scheduled task. If this parameter value is not specified, the default value is ScalingConfigurationId.
    scaling_configuration_name = ""

    # internet_charge_type - (Optional) Network billing type, Values: PayByBandwidth or PayByTraffic. If this parameter value is not specified, the default value is PayByBandwidth.
    internet_charge_type = ""

    # internet_max_bandwidth_in - (Optional) Maximum incoming bandwidth from the public network, measured in Mbps (Mega bit per second). The value range is [1,200].
    internet_max_bandwidth_in = ""

    # internet_max_bandwidth_out - (Optional) Maximum outgoing bandwidth from the public network, measured in Mbps (Mega bit per second). The value range for PayByBandwidth is [1,100].
    internet_max_bandwidth_out = ""

    # system_disk_category - (Optional) Category of the system disk. The parameter value options are cloud and ephemeral. 
    system_disk_category = ""

    # data_disk - (Optional) DataDisk mappings to attach to ecs instance. See [Block datadisk](#block-datadisk) below for details. 
    data_disk = ""

    # instance_ids - (Optional) ID of the ECS instance to be attached to the scaling group after it is enabled. You can input up to 20 IDs. 
    instance_ids = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The scaling configuration ID.
    # "active" - Wether the current scaling configuration is actived.
    # "image_id" - The ecs instance Image id.
    # "instance_type" - The ecs instance type.
    # "io_optimized" - The ecs instance whether I/O optimized.
    # "security_group_id" - ID of the security group to which a newly created instance belongs.
    # "scaling_configuration_name" - Name of scaling configuration.
    # "internet_charge_type" - Internet charge type of ecs instance.
}
alicloud-resource-ess-scaling-configurat.description: Provides a ESS scaling configuration resource.

alicloud-resource-ess-scaling-group.body:
resource "alicloud_ess_scaling_group" "$1" {
    # max_size - (Required) Maximum number of ECS instances in the scaling group. Value range: [0, 100].
    max_size = ""

    # min_size - (Required) Minimum number of ECS instances in the scaling group. Value range: [0, 100].
    min_size = ""

    # scaling_group_name - (Optional) Name shown for the scaling group, which must contain 2-40 characters (English or Chinese). If this parameter is not specified, the default value is ScalingGroupId.
    scaling_group_name = ""

    # default_cooldown - (Optional) Default cool-down time (in seconds) of the scaling group. Value range: [0, 86400]. The default value is 300s.
    default_cooldown = ""

    # vswitch_id - (Optional) The virtual switch ID which the ecs instance to be create in.
    vswitch_id = ""

    # removal_policies - (Optional) RemovalPolicy is used to select the ECS instances you want to remove from the scaling group when multiple candidates for removal exist. Optional values:
    removal_policies = ""

    # db_instance_ids - (Optional) If an RDS instance is specified in the scaling group, the scaling group automatically attaches the Intranet IP addresses of its ECS instances to the RDS access whitelist.
    db_instance_ids = ""

    # loadbalancer_ids - (Optional) If a Server Load Balancer instance is specified in the scaling group, the scaling group automatically attaches its ECS instances to the Server Load Balancer instance.
    loadbalancer_ids = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The scaling group ID.
    # "min_size" - The minimum number of ECS instances.
    # "max_size" - The maximum number of ECS instances.
    # "scaling_group_name" - The name of the scaling group.
    # "default_cooldown" - The default cool-down of the scaling group.
    # "removal_policies" - The removal policy used to select the ECS instance to remove from the scaling group.
    # "db_instance_ids" - The db instance id which the ECS instance attached to.
    # "loadbalancer_ids" - The slb instance id which the ECS instance attached to.
}
alicloud-resource-ess-scaling-group.description: Provides a ESS scaling group resource.

alicloud-resource-ess-scaling-rule.body:
resource "alicloud_ess_scaling_rule" "$1" {
    # adjustment_value - (Required) Adjusted value of a scaling rule. Value range:
    adjustment_value = ""

    # adjustment_type - (Required) Adjustment mode of a scaling rule. Optional values:
    adjustment_type = ""

    # scaling_group_id - (Required) ID of the scaling group of a scaling rule.
    scaling_group_id = ""

    # scaling_rule_name - (Optional) Name shown for the scaling rule, which is a string containing 2 to 40 English or Chinese characters.
    scaling_rule_name = ""

    # cooldown - (Optional) Cool-down time of a scaling rule. Value range: [0, 86,400], in seconds. The default value is empty.
    cooldown = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The scaling rule ID.
    # "scaling_group_id" - The id of scaling group.
    # "ari" - Unique identifier of a scaling rule.
    # "adjustment_type" - Adjustment mode of a scaling rule.
    # "adjustment_value" - Adjustment value of a scaling rule.
    # "scaling_rule_name" - Name of a scaling rule.
    # "cooldown" - Cool-down time of a scaling rule.
}
alicloud-resource-ess-scaling-rule.description: Provides a ESS scaling rule resource.

alicloud-resource-ess-schedule.body:
resource "alicloud_ess_schedule" "$1" {
    # launch_time - (Required) Operations performed when the scheduled task is triggered. Fill in the unique identifier of the scaling rule.
    launch_time = ""

    # scheduled_action - (Required) Operations performed when the scheduled task is triggered. Fill in the unique identifier of the scaling rule.
    scheduled_action = ""

    # scheduled_task_name - (Optional) Display name of the scheduled task, which must be 2-40 characters (English or Chinese) long.
    scheduled_task_name = ""

    # description - (Optional) Description of the scheduled task, which is 2-200 characters (English or Chinese) long.
    description = ""

    # launch_expiration_time - (Optional) Time period within which the failed scheduled task is retried. The default value is 600s. Value range: [0, 21600]
    launch_expiration_time = ""

    # recurrence_type - (Optional) Type of the scheduled task to be repeated. RecurrenceType, RecurrenceValue and RecurrenceEndTime must be specified. Optional values:
    recurrence_type = ""

    # recurrence_value - (Optional) Value of the scheduled task to be repeated. RecurrenceType, RecurrenceValue and RecurrenceEndTime must be specified.
    recurrence_value = ""

    # recurrence_end_time - (Optional) End time of the scheduled task to be repeated. The date format follows the ISO8601 standard and uses UTC time. It is in the format of YYYY-MM-DDThh:mmZ. A time point 90 days after creation or modification cannot be entered. RecurrenceType, RecurrenceValue and RecurrenceEndTime must be specified.                                  
    recurrence_end_time = ""

    # task_enabled - (Optional) Whether to enable the scheduled task. The default value is true.
    task_enabled = ""

    # id - (Optional) The schedule task ID.
    id = ""

    # scheduled_action - (Optional) The action of schedule task.
    scheduled_action = ""

    # launch_time - (Optional) The time of schedule task be triggered.
    launch_time = ""

    # scheduled_task_name - (Optional) The name of schedule task.
    scheduled_task_name = ""

    # description - (Optional) The description of schedule task.
    description = ""

    # task_enabled - (Optional) Wether the task is enabled.
    task_enabled = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}

alicloud-resource-instance.body:
resource "alicloud_instance" "$1" {
    # security_groups - (Required)  A list of security group ids to associate with.
    security_groups = ""

    # io_optimized - (Required) Valid values are `none`, `optimized`, If `optimized`, the launched ECS instance will be I/O optimized.
    io_optimized = ""

    # instance_type - (Required) The type of instance to start.
    instance_type = ""

    # image_id - (Required) The Image to use for the instance. ECS instance's image can be replaced via changing 'image_id'.
    image_id = ""

    # availability_zone - (Optional) The Zone to start the instance in.
    availability_zone = ""

    # instance_name - (Optional) The name of the ECS. This instance_name can have a string of 2 to 128 characters, must contain only alphanumeric characters or hyphens, such as "-",".","_", and must not begin or end with a hyphen, and must not begin with http:// or https://. If not specified, 
    instance_name = ""

    # allocate_public_ip - (Optional) Associate a public ip address with an instance in a VPC or Classic. Boolean value, Default is false.
    allocate_public_ip = ""

    # system_disk_category - (Optional) Valid values are `cloud`, `cloud_efficiency`, `cloud_ssd`, For I/O optimized instance type, `cloud_ssd` and `cloud_efficiency` disks are supported. For non I/O Optimized instance type, `cloud` disk are supported. 
    system_disk_category = ""

    # system_disk_size - (Optional) Size of the system disk, value range: 40GB ~ 500GB. Default is 40GB. ECS instance's system disk can be reset when replacing system disk.
    system_disk_size = ""

    # description - (Optional) Description of the instance, This description can have a string of 2 to 256 characters, It cannot begin with http:// or https://. Default value is null.
    description = ""

    # internet_charge_type - (Optional) Internet charge type of the instance, Valid values are `PayByBandwidth`, `PayByTraffic`. Default is `PayByBandwidth`.
    internet_charge_type = ""

    # internet_max_bandwidth_in - (Optional) Maximum incoming bandwidth from the public network, measured in Mbps (Mega bit per second). Value range: [1, 200]. If this value is not specified, then automatically sets it to 200 Mbps.
    internet_max_bandwidth_in = ""

    # internet_max_bandwidth_out - (Optional) Maximum outgoing bandwidth to the public network, measured in Mbps (Mega bit per second). Value range:  [0, 100], If this value is not specified, then automatically sets it to 0 Mbps.
    internet_max_bandwidth_out = ""

    # host_name - (Optional) Host name of the ECS, which is a string of at least two characters. “hostname” cannot start or end with “.” or “-“. In addition, two or more consecutive “.” or “-“ symbols are not allowed. On Windows, the host name can contain a maximum of 15 characters, which can be a combination of uppercase/lowercase letters, numerals, and “-“. The host name cannot contain dots (“.”) or contain only numeric characters.
    host_name = ""

    # password - (Optional) Password to an instance is a string of 8 to 30 characters. It must contain uppercase/lowercase letters and numerals, but cannot contain special symbols. In order to take effect new password, the instance will be restarted after modifying the password.
    password = ""

    # vswitch_id - (Optional) The virtual switch ID to launch in VPC. If you want to create instances in VPC network, this parameter must be set.
    vswitch_id = ""

    # instance_charge_type - (Optional) Valid values are `PrePaid`, `PostPaid`, The default is `PostPaid`.
    instance_charge_type = ""

    # period - (Optional) The time that you have bought the resource, in month. Only valid when instance_charge_type is set as `PrePaid`. Value range [1, 12].
    period = ""

    # tags - (Optional) A mapping of tags to assign to the resource.
    tags = ""

    # user_data - (Optional) The user data to provide when launching the instance.
    user_data = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The instance ID.
    # "availability_zone" - The Zone to start the instance in.
    # "instance_name" - The instance name.
    # "host_name" - The instance host name.
    # "description" - The instance description.
    # "status" - The instance status.
    # "image_id" - The instance Image Id.
    # "instance_type" - The instance type.
    # "instance_network_type" - The instance network type and it has two values: "vpc" and "classic".
    # "io_optimized" - The instance whether I/O optimized.
    # "private_ip" - The instance private ip.
    # "public_ip" - The instance public ip.
    # "vswitch_id" - If the instance created in VPC, then this value is  virtual switch ID.
    # "tags" - The instance tags, use jsonencode(item) to display the value.
}

alicloud-resource-nat-gateway.body:
resource "alicloud_nat_gateway" "$1" {
    # bandwidth_packages - (Required) A list of bandwidth packages for the nat gatway.
    bandwidth_packages = ""

    # vpc_id - (Optional) (Required, Forces New Resorce) The VPC ID.
    vpc_id = ""

    # spec - (Optional) (Required, Forces New Resorce) The specification of the nat gateway. Valid values are `Small`, `Middle` and `Large`. Details refer to [Nat Gateway Specification](https://help.aliyun.com/document_detail/42757.html?spm=5176.doc32322.6.559.kFNBzv)
    spec = ""

    # name - (Optional) Name of the nat gateway. The value can have a string of 2 to 128 characters, must contain only alphanumeric characters or hyphens, such as "-",".","_", and must not begin or end with a hyphen, and must not begin with http:// or https://. Defaults to null.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) Description of the nat gateway, This description can have a string of 2 to 256 characters, It cannot begin with http:// or https://. Defaults to null.
    description = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The ID of the nat gateway.
    # "name" - The name of the nat gateway.
    # "description" - The description of the nat gateway.
    # "spec" - The specification of the nat gateway.
    # "vpc_id" - The VPC ID for the nat gateway.
    # "bandwidth_package_ids" - A list ID of the bandwidth packages, and split them with commas
    # "snat_table_ids" - The nat gateway will auto create a snap and forward item, the "snat_table_ids" is the created one.
    # "forward_table_ids" - The nat gateway will auto create a snap and forward item, the "forward_table_ids" is the created one.
}
alicloud-resource-nat-gateway.description: Provides a resource to create a VPC NAT Gateway. ~> **NOTE:** alicloud_nat_gateway must depends on alicloud_vswitch.

alicloud-resource-route-entry.body:

    nexthop_id = ""

alicloud-resource-security-group.body:

alicloud-resource-security-group.description: Provides a security group resource. ~> **NOTE:** `alicloud_security_group` is used to build and manage a security group, and `alicloud_security_group_rule` can define ingress or egress rules for it.

alicloud-resource-security-group-rule.body:
resource "alicloud_security_group_rule" "$1" {
    # security_group_id - (Required) The security group to apply this rule to.
    security_group_id = ""

    # port_range - (Required) The range of port numbers relevant to the IP protocol. When the protocol is tcp or udp, the default port number range is 1-65535. For example, `1/200` means that the range of the port numbers is 1-200.
    port_range = ""

    # ip_protocol - (Required) The protocol. Can be `tcp`, `udp`, `icmp`, `gre` or `all`.
    ip_protocol = ""

    # type - (Required) The type of rule being created. Valid options are `ingress` (inbound) or `egress` (outbound).
    type = ""

    # nic_type - (Optional) (Optional, Forces new resource) Network type, can be either `internet` or `intranet`, the default value is `internet`.
    nic_type = ""

    # policy - (Optional) (Optional, Forces new resource) Authorization policy, can be either `accept` or `drop`, the default value is `accept`.
    policy = ""

    # priority - (Optional) (Optional, Forces new resource) Authorization policy priority, with parameter values: `1-100`, default value: 1.
    priority = ""

    # cidr_ip - (Optional) (Optional, Forces new resource) The target IP address range. The default value is 0.0.0.0/0 (which means no restriction will be applied). Other supported formats include 10.159.6.18/12. Only IPv4 is supported.
    cidr_ip = ""

    # source_security_group_id - (Optional) (Optional, Forces new resource) The target security group ID within the same region. Either the `source_security_group_id` or `cidr_ip` must be set. If both are set, then `cidr_ip` is authorized by default. If this field is specified, but no `cidr_ip` is specified, the `nic_type` can only select `intranet`.
    source_security_group_id = ""

    # source_group_owner_account - (Optional) (Optional, Forces new resource) The Alibaba Cloud user account Id of the target security group when security groups are authorized across accounts.  This parameter is invalid if `cidr_ip` has already been set.
    source_group_owner_account = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The ID of the security group rule
    # "type" - The type of rule, "ingress" or "egress"
    # "name" - The name of the security group
    # "port_range" - The range of port numbers
    # "ip_protocol" - The protocol of the security group rule
}
alicloud-resource-security-group-rule.description:
Provides a security group rule resource.
Represents a single `ingress` or `egress` group rule, which can be added to external Security Groups. ~> **NOTE:**  `nic_type` should set to `intranet` when security group type is `vpc`. In this situation it does not distinguish between intranet and internet, the rule is effective on them both.

alicloud-resource-slb.body:
resource "alicloud_slb" "$1" {
    # name - (Optional) The name of the SLB. This name must be unique within your AliCloud account, can have a maximum of 80 characters,
    name = ""

    # internet - (Optional) (Optional, Forces New Resource) If true, the SLB addressType will be internet, false will be intranet, Default is false. If load balancer launched in VPC, this value must be "false".
    internet = ""

    # internet_charge_type - (Optional) (Optional, Forces New Resource) Valid
    internet_charge_type = ""

    # bandwidth - (Optional) Valid
    bandwidth = ""

    # listener - (Optional) Additional SLB listener. See [Block listener](#block-listener) below for details.
    listener = ""

    # vswitch_id - (Optional) (Required for a VPC SLB, Forces New Resource) The VSwitch ID to launch in.
    vswitch_id = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The ID of the load balancer.
    # "name" - The name of the load balancer.
    # "internet" - The internet of the load balancer.
    # "internet_charge_type" - The internet_charge_type of the load balancer.
    # "bandwidth" - The bandwidth of the load balancer.
    # "vswitch_id" - The VSwitch ID of the load balancer. Only available on SLB launched in a VPC.
    # "address" - The IP address of the load balancer.
}
alicloud-resource-slb.description: Provides an Application Load Balancer resource.

    # "cidr_block" - The CIDR block for the switch.

docker-resource-image.description:
-> **Note:** The initial (current) version of this resource can only pull **public** images **from the official Docker Hub Registry**. Pulls a Docker image to a given Docker host from a Docker Registry. This resource will *not* pull new layers of the image automatically unless used in
conjunction with [`docker_registry_image`](/docs/providers/docker/d/registry_image.html)
data source to update the `pull_triggers` field.

[docker\_container](/docs/providers/docker/r/container.html)
to create virtual networks within the docker environment.

openstack-datasource-dns-zone-v2.body:
data "openstack_dns_zone_v2" "$1" {
    # region - (Optional) The region in which to obtain the V2 DNS client. A DNS client is needed to retrieve zone ids. If omitted, the `region` argument of the provider is used.
    region = ""

    # name - (Optional) The name of the zone.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) A description of the zone.
    description = ""

    # email - (Optional) The email contact for the zone record.
    email = ""

    # status - (Optional) The zone's status.
    status = ""

    # ttl - (Optional) The time to live (TTL) of the zone.
    ttl = ""

    # type - (Optional) The type of the zone. Can either be `PRIMARY` or `SECONDARY`.
    type = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" is set to the ID of the found zone. In addition, the following attributes
are exported:
    # "region" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "type" - (Optional) The type of the zone. Can either be "PRIMARY" or "SECONDARY".
    # "name" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "type" - (Optional) The type of the zone. Can either be "PRIMARY" or "SECONDARY".
    # "email" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "type" - (Optional) The type of the zone. Can either be "PRIMARY" or "SECONDARY".
    # "type" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "type" - (Optional) The type of the zone. Can either be "PRIMARY" or "SECONDARY".
    # "ttl" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "type" - (Optional) The type of the zone. Can either be "PRIMARY" or "SECONDARY".
    # "description" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "type" - (Optional) The type of the zone. Can either be "PRIMARY" or "SECONDARY".
    # "status" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "type" - (Optional) The type of the zone. Can either be "PRIMARY" or "SECONDARY".
    # "attributes" - Attributes of the DNS Service scheduler.
    # "type" - (Optional) The type of the zone. Can either be "PRIMARY" or "SECONDARY".
    # "masters" - An array of master DNS servers. When "type" is  "SECONDARY".
    # "type" - (Optional) The type of the zone. Can either be "PRIMARY" or "SECONDARY".
    # "created_at" - The time the zone was created.
    # "type" - (Optional) The type of the zone. Can either be "PRIMARY" or "SECONDARY".
    # "updated_at" - The time the zone was last updated.
    # "type" - (Optional) The type of the zone. Can either be "PRIMARY" or "SECONDARY".

openstack-resource-blockstorage-volume-a.body:
resource "openstack_blockstorage_volume_attach_v2" "$1" {
    # volume_id - (Required) The ID of the Volume to attach to an Instance.
    volume_id = ""

    # host_name - (Required) The host to attach the volume to.
    host_name = ""

    # region - (Optional) The region in which to obtain the V2 Block Storage   client. A Block Storage client is needed to create a volume attachment.   If omitted, the `region` argument of the provider is used. Changing this   creates a new volume attachment.
    region = ""

    # attach_mode - (Optional) Specify whether to attach the volume as Read-Only (`ro`) or Read-Write (`rw`). Only values of `ro` and `rw` are accepted. If left unspecified, the Block Storage API will apply a default of `rw`.
    attach_mode = ""

    # device - (Optional) The device to tell the Block Storage service this volume will be attached as. This is purely for informational purposes. You can specify `auto` or a device such as `/dev/vdc`.
    device = ""

    # initiator - (Optional) The iSCSI initiator string to make the connection.
    initiator = ""

    # ip_address - (Optional) The IP address of the `host_name` above.
    ip_address = ""

    # multipath - (Optional) Whether to connect to this volume via multipath.
    multipath = ""

    # os_type - (Optional) The iSCSI initiator OS type.
    os_type = ""

    # platform - (Optional) The iSCSI initiator platform.
    platform = ""

    # wwpn - (Optional) An array of wwpn strings. Used for Fibre Channel connections.
    wwpn = ""

    # wwnn - (Optional) A wwnn name. Used for Fibre Channel connections.
    wwnn = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "data" - This is a map of key/value pairs that contain the connection information. You will want to pass this information to a provisioner script to finalize the connection. See below for more information.
    # "driver_volume_type" - The storage driver that the volume is based on.
    # "mount_point_base" - A mount point base name for shared storage.
}
openstack-resource-blockstorage-volume-a.description:
This resource is experimental and may be removed in the future! Feedback
is requested if you find this resource useful or if you find any problems
with it. Creates a general purpose attachment connection to a Block
Storage volume using the OpenStack Block Storage (Cinder) v2 API.
Depending on your Block Storage service configuration, this
resource can assist in attaching a volume to a non-OpenStack resource
such as a bare-metal server or a remote virtual machine in a
different cloud provider. This does not actually attach a volume to an instance. Please use
the `openstack_compute_volume_attach_v2` resource for that.

resource "openstack_compute_floatingip_v2" "$1" {
    # pool - (Required) The name of the pool from which to obtain the floating   IP. Changing this creates a new floating IP.
    pool = ""

    # region - (Optional) The region in which to obtain the V2 Compute client.   A Compute client is needed to create a floating IP that can be used with   a compute instance. If omitted, the `region` argument of the provider   is used. Changing this creates a new floating IP (which may or may not   have a different address).

    # "region" - See Argument Reference above.

    # "address" - The actual floating IP address itself.
    # "pool" - (Required) The name of the pool from which to obtain the floating   IP. Changing this creates a new floating IP.
    # "fixed_ip" - The fixed IP address corresponding to the floating IP.
    # "pool" - (Required) The name of the pool from which to obtain the floating   IP. Changing this creates a new floating IP.
    # "instance_id" - UUID of the compute instance associated with the floating IP.
    # "pool" - (Required) The name of the pool from which to obtain the floating   IP. Changing this creates a new floating IP.
}
openstack-resource-compute-floatingip-v2.description:
Manages a V2 floating IP resource within OpenStack Nova (compute)
that can be used for compute instances.
These are similar to Neutron (networking) floating IP resources,
but only networking floating IPs can be used with load balancers.

openstack-resource-compute-instance-v2.body:
resource "openstack_compute_instance_v2" "$1" {
    # contents - (Required) The contents of the file. Limited to 255 bytes.
    contents = ""

    # file - (Required) The absolute path of the destination file.
    file = ""

    # source_type - (Required) The source type of the device. Must be one of   "blank", "image", "volume", or "snapshot". Changing this creates a new   server.
    source_type = ""

    # name - (Required) A unique name for the resource.
    name = ""

    # region - (Optional) The region in which to create the server instance. If   omitted, the `region` argument of the provider is used. Changing this   creates a new server.
    region = ""

    # image_id - (Optional) (Optional; Required if `image_name` is empty and not booting   from a volume. Do not specify if booting from a volume.) The image ID of   the desired image for the server. Changing this creates a new server.
    image_id = ""

    # image_name - (Optional) (Optional; Required if `image_id` is empty and not booting   from a volume. Do not specify if booting from a volume.) The name of the   desired image for the server. Changing this creates a new server.
    image_name = ""

    # flavor_id - (Optional) (Optional; Required if `flavor_name` is empty) The flavor ID of   the desired flavor for the server. Changing this resizes the existing server.
    flavor_id = ""

    # flavor_name - (Optional) (Optional; Required if `flavor_id` is empty) The name of the   desired flavor for the server. Changing this resizes the existing server.
    flavor_name = ""

    # user_data - (Optional) The user data to provide when launching the instance.   Changing this creates a new server.
    user_data = ""

    # security_groups - (Optional) An array of one or more security group names   to associate with the server. Changing this results in adding/removing   security groups from the existing server. *Note*: When attaching the   instance to networks using Ports, place the security groups on the Port   and not the instance.
    security_groups = ""

    # availability_zone - (Optional) The availability zone in which to create   the server. Changing this creates a new server.
    availability_zone = ""

    # network - (Optional) An array of one or more networks to attach to the   instance. The network object structure is documented below. Changing this   creates a new server.
    network = ""

    # metadata - (Optional) Metadata key/value pairs to make available from   within the instance. Changing this updates the existing server metadata.
    metadata = ""

    # config_drive - (Optional) Whether to use the config_drive feature to   configure the instance. Changing this creates a new server.
    config_drive = ""

    # admin_pass - (Optional) The administrative password to assign to the server.   Changing this changes the root password on the existing server.
    admin_pass = ""

    # key_pair - (Optional) The name of a key pair to put on the server. The key   pair must already be created and associated with the tenant's account.   Changing this creates a new server.
    key_pair = ""

    # block_device - (Optional) Configuration of block devices. The block_device   structure is documented below. Changing this creates a new server.   You can specify multiple block devices which will create an instance with   multiple disks. This configuration is very flexible, so please see the   following [reference](http://docs.openstack.org/developer/nova/block_device_mapping.html)   for more information.
    block_device = ""

    # scheduler_hints - (Optional) Provide the Nova scheduler with hints on how   the instance should be launched. The available hints are described below.
    scheduler_hints = ""

    # personality - (Optional) Customize the personality of an instance by   defining one or more files and their contents. The personality structure   is described below.
    personality = ""

    # stop_before_destroy - (Optional) Whether to try stop instance gracefully   before destroying it, thus giving chance for guest OS daemons to stop correctly.   If instance doesn't stop within timeout, it will be destroyed anyway.
    stop_before_destroy = ""

    # force_delete - (Optional) Whether to force the OpenStack instance to be   forcefully deleted. This is useful for environments that have reclaim / soft   deletion enabled.
    force_delete = ""

    # uuid - (Optional) (Required unless `port`  or `name` is provided) The network UUID to   attach to the server. Changing this creates a new server.
    uuid = ""

    # name - (Optional) (Required unless `uuid` or `port` is provided) The human-readable   name of the network. Changing this creates a new server.
    name = ""

    # port - (Optional) (Required unless `uuid` or `name` is provided) The port UUID of a   network to attach to the server. Changing this creates a new server.
    port = ""

    # access_network - (Optional) Specifies if this network should be used for   provisioning access. Accepts true or false. Defaults to false.
    access_network = ""

    # uuid - (Optional) (Required unless `source_type` is set to `"blank"` ) The UUID of   the image, volume, or snapshot. Changing this creates a new server.
    uuid = ""

    # volume_size - (Optional) The size of the volume to create (in gigabytes). Required   in the following combinations: source=image and destination=volume,   source=blank and destination=local, and source=blank and destination=volume.   Changing this creates a new server.
    volume_size = ""

    # boot_index - (Optional) The boot index of the volume. It defaults to 0.   Changing this creates a new server.
    boot_index = ""

    # destination_type - (Optional) The type that gets created. Possible values   are "volume" and "local". Changing this creates a new server.
    destination_type = ""

    # delete_on_termination - (Optional) Delete the volume / block device upon   termination of the instance. Defaults to false. Changing this creates a   new server.
    delete_on_termination = ""

    # group - (Optional) A UUID of a Server Group. The instance will be placed   into that group.
    group = ""

    # different_host - (Optional) A list of instance UUIDs. The instance will   be scheduled on a different host than all other instances.
    different_host = ""

    # same_host - (Optional) A list of instance UUIDs. The instance will be   scheduled on the same host of those specified.
    same_host = ""

    # query - (Optional) A conditional query that a compute node must pass in   order to host an instance.
    query = ""

    # target_cell - (Optional) The name of a cell to host the instance.
    target_cell = ""

    # build_near_host_ip - (Optional) An IP Address in CIDR form. The instance   will be placed on a compute node that is in the same subnet.
    build_near_host_ip = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "region" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "contents" - (Required) The contents of the file. Limited to 255 bytes.
    # "name" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "contents" - (Required) The contents of the file. Limited to 255 bytes.
    # "access_ip_v4" - The first detected Fixed IPv4 address _or_ the
    # "contents" - (Required) The contents of the file. Limited to 255 bytes.
    # "access_ip_v6" - The first detected Fixed IPv6 address.
    # "contents" - (Required) The contents of the file. Limited to 255 bytes.
    # "metadata" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "contents" - (Required) The contents of the file. Limited to 255 bytes.
    # "security_groups" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "contents" - (Required) The contents of the file. Limited to 255 bytes.
    # "flavor_id" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "contents" - (Required) The contents of the file. Limited to 255 bytes.

    # "network/uuid" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "contents" - (Required) The contents of the file. Limited to 255 bytes.
    # "network/name" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "contents" - (Required) The contents of the file. Limited to 255 bytes.
    # "network/port" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "contents" - (Required) The contents of the file. Limited to 255 bytes.
    # "network/fixed_ip_v4" - The Fixed IPv4 address of the Instance on that
    # "contents" - (Required) The contents of the file. Limited to 255 bytes.
    # "network/fixed_ip_v6" - The Fixed IPv6 address of the Instance on that

    # "contents" - (Required) The contents of the file. Limited to 255 bytes.
    # "all_metadata" - Contains all instance metadata, even metadata not set
    # "contents" - (Required) The contents of the file. Limited to 255 bytes.
}

openstack-resource-compute-secgroup-v2.body:
resource "openstack_compute_secgroup_v2" "$1" {
    # ip_protocol - (Required) The protocol type that will be allowed. Changing this creates a new security group rule.
    ip_protocol = ""

    # to_port - (Required) An integer representing the upper bound of the port range to open. Changing this creates a new security group rule.
    to_port = ""

    # from_port - (Required) An integer representing the lower bound of the port range to open. Changing this creates a new security group rule.
    from_port = ""

    # description - (Required) A description for the security group. Changing this   updates the `description` of an existing security group.
    description = ""

    # name - (Required) A unique name for the security group. Changing this   updates the `name` of an existing security group.
    name = ""

    # region - (Optional) The region in which to obtain the V2 Compute client.   A Compute client is needed to create a security group. If omitted, the   `region` argument of the provider is used. Changing this creates a new   security group.
    region = ""

    # rule - (Optional) A rule describing how the security group operates. The   rule object structure is documented below. Changing this updates the   security group rules. As shown in the example above, multiple rule blocks   may be used.
    rule = ""

    # cidr - (Optional) Required if `from_group_id` or `self` is empty. The IP range that will be the source of network traffic to the security group. Use 0.0.0.0/0 to allow all IP addresses. Changing this creates a new security group rule. Cannot be combined with `from_group_id` or `self`.
    cidr = ""

    # from_group_id - (Optional) Required if `cidr` or `self` is empty. The ID of a group from which to forward traffic to the parent group. Changing this creates a new security group rule. Cannot be combined with `cidr` or `self`.
    from_group_id = ""

    # self - (Optional) Required if `cidr` and `from_group_id` is empty. If true, the security group itself will be added as a source to this ingress rule. Cannot be combined with `cidr` or `from_group_id`.
    self = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "region" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "self" - (Optional) Required if "cidr" and "from_group_id" is empty. If true, the security group itself will be added as a source to this ingress rule. Cannot be combined with "cidr" or "from_group_id".
    # "name" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "self" - (Optional) Required if "cidr" and "from_group_id" is empty. If true, the security group itself will be added as a source to this ingress rule. Cannot be combined with "cidr" or "from_group_id".
    # "description" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "self" - (Optional) Required if "cidr" and "from_group_id" is empty. If true, the security group itself will be added as a source to this ingress rule. Cannot be combined with "cidr" or "from_group_id".
    # "rule" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "self" - (Optional) Required if "cidr" and "from_group_id" is empty. If true, the security group itself will be added as a source to this ingress rule. Cannot be combined with "cidr" or "from_group_id".
}
openstack-resource-compute-secgroup-v2.description: Manages a V2 security group resource within OpenStack.

If this happens, Terraform will wish to update the device upon subsequent applying which will cause the volume to be detached and reattached indefinitely. Please use with caution.

There is a chance that the device specified in Terraform will not be the same device the hypervisor chose. openstack-resource-fw-policy-v1.body:
resource "openstack_fw_policy_v1" "$1" {
    # region - (Optional) The region in which to obtain the v1 networking client.   A networking client is needed to create a firewall policy. If omitted, the   `region` argument of the provider is used. Changing this creates a new   firewall policy.
    region = ""

    # name - (Optional) A name for the firewall policy. Changing this   updates the `name` of an existing firewall policy.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) A description for the firewall policy. Changing   this updates the `description` of an existing firewall policy.
    description = ""

    # rules - (Optional) An array of one or more firewall rules that comprise   the policy. Changing this results in adding/removing rules from the   existing firewall policy.
    rules = ""

    # audited - (Optional) Audit status of the firewall policy   (must be "true" or "false" if provided - defaults to "false").   This status is set to "false" whenever the firewall policy or any of its   rules are changed. Changing this updates the `audited` status of an existing   firewall policy.
    audited = ""

    # shared - (Optional) Sharing status of the firewall policy (must be "true"   or "false" if provided). If this is "true" the policy is visible to, and   can be used in, firewalls in other tenants. Changing this updates the   `shared` status of an existing firewall policy. Only administrative users   can specify if the policy should be shared.
    shared = ""

    # value_specs - (Optional) Map of additional options.

    # "region" - See Argument Reference above.

    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.

    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.

}

openstack-resource-identity-project-v3.body:
resource "openstack_identity_project_v3" "$1" {
    # description - (Optional) A description of the project.
    description = ""

    # domain_id - (Optional) The domain this project belongs to.
    domain_id = ""

    # enabled - (Optional) Whether the project is enabled or disabled. Valid values are `true` and `false`.
    enabled = ""

    # is_domain - (Optional) Whether this project is a domain. Valid values are `true` and `false`.
    is_domain = ""

    # name - (Optional) The name of the project.
    name = ""

    # parent_id - (Optional) The parent of this project.
    parent_id = ""

    # region - (Optional) The region in which to obtain the V3 Keystone client.   If omitted, the `region` argument of the provider is used. Changing this   creates a new User.
    region = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "domain_id" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "region" - (Optional) The region in which to obtain the V3 Keystone client.   If omitted, the "region" argument of the provider is used. Changing this   creates a new User.
    # "parent_id" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "region" - (Optional) The region in which to obtain the V3 Keystone client.   If omitted, the "region" argument of the provider is used. Changing this   creates a new User.
}
openstack-resource-identity-project-v3.description:
Manages a V3 Project resource within OpenStack Keystone. Note: You _must_ have admin privileges in your OpenStack cloud to use
this resource.

openstack-resource-identity-user-v3.body:
resource "openstack_identity_user_v3" "$1" {
    # rule - (Required) A list of authentication plugins that the user must
    rule = ""

    # description - (Optional) A description of the user.
    description = ""

    # default_project_id - (Optional) The default project this user belongs to.
    default_project_id = ""

    # domain_id - (Optional) The domain this user belongs to.
    domain_id = ""

    # enabled - (Optional) Whether the user is enabled or disabled. Valid values are `true` and `false`.
    enabled = ""

    # extra - (Optional) Free-form key/value pairs of extra information.
    extra = ""

    # ignore_change_password_upon_first_use - (Optional) User will not have to change their password upon first use. Valid values are `true` and `false`.
    ignore_change_password_upon_first_use = ""

    # ignore_password_expiry - (Optional) User's password will not expire. Valid values are `true` and `false`.
    ignore_password_expiry = ""

    # ignore_lockout_failure_attempts - (Optional) User will not have a failure lockout placed on their account. Valid values are `true` and `false`.
    ignore_lockout_failure_attempts = ""

    # multi_factor_auth_enabled - (Optional) Whether to enable multi-factor authentication. Valid values are `true` and `false`.
    multi_factor_auth_enabled = ""

    # multi_factor_auth_rule - (Optional) A multi-factor authentication rule. The structure is documented below. Please see the [Ocata release notes](https://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/keystone/ocata.html) for more information on how to use mulit-factor rules.
    multi_factor_auth_rule = ""

    # name - (Optional) The name of the user.
    name = ""

    # password - (Optional) The password for the user.
    password = ""

    # region - (Optional) The region in which to obtain the V3 Keystone client.   If omitted, the `region` argument of the provider is used. Changing this   creates a new User.
    region = ""

    # region - (Optional) The region in which to obtain the V3 Keystone client.   If omitted, the `region` argument of the provider is used. Changing this   creates a new User.
    region = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "domain_id" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "region" - (Optional) The region in which to obtain the V3 Keystone client.   If omitted, the "region" argument of the provider is used. Changing this   creates a new User.
}
openstack-resource-identity-user-v3.description:
Manages a V3 User resource within OpenStack Keystone. Note: You _must_ have admin privileges in your OpenStack cloud to use
this resource.

openstack-resource-images-image-v2.body:
resource "openstack_images_image_v2" "$1" {
    # name - (Required) The name of the image.
    name = ""

    # disk_format - (Required) The disk format. Must be one of  "ami", "ari", "aki", "vhd", "vmdk", "raw", "qcow2", "vdi", "iso".
    disk_format = ""

    # container_format - (Required) The container format. Must be one of  "ami", "ari", "aki", "bare", "ovf".
    container_format = ""

    # local_file_path - (Optional) This is the filepath of the raw image file  that will be uploaded to Glance. Conflicts with `image_source_url`.
    local_file_path = ""

    # image_cache_path - (Optional) This is the directory where the images will  be downloaded. Images will be stored with a filename corresponding to  the url's md5 hash. Defaults to "$HOME/.terraform/image_cache"
    image_cache_path = ""

    # image_source_url - (Optional) This is the url of the raw image that will  be downloaded in the `image_cache_path` before being uploaded to Glance.  Glance is able to download image from internet but the `gophercloud` library  does not yet provide a way to do so.  Conflicts with `local_file_path`.
    image_source_url = ""

    # min_disk_gb - (Optional) Amount of disk space (in GB) required to boot image.  Defaults to 0.
    min_disk_gb = ""

    # min_ram_mb - (Optional) Amount of ram (in MB) required to boot image.  Defauts to 0.
    min_ram_mb = ""

    # properties - (Optional) A map of key/value pairs to set freeform   information about an image.
    properties = ""

    # protected - (Optional) If true, image will not be deletable.  Defaults to false.
    protected = ""

    # region - (Optional) The region in which to obtain the V2 Glance client.   A Glance client is needed to create an Image that can be used with   a compute instance. If omitted, the `region` argument of the provider   is used. Changing this creates a new Image.
    region = ""

    # tags - (Optional) The tags of the image. It must be a list of strings.   At this time, it is not possible to delete all tags of an image.
    tags = ""

    # visibility - (Optional) The visibility of the image. Must be one of  "public", "private", "community", or "shared". The ability to set the  visibility depends upon the configuration of the OpenStack cloud.
    visibility = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "checksum" - The checksum of the data associated with the image.
    # "visibility" - (Optional) The visibility of the image. Must be one of  "public", "private", "community", or "shared". The ability to set the  visibility depends upon the configuration of the OpenStack cloud.
    # "container_format" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "visibility" - (Optional) The visibility of the image. Must be one of  "public", "private", "community", or "shared". The ability to set the  visibility depends upon the configuration of the OpenStack cloud.
    # "created_at" - The date the image was created.
    # "visibility" - (Optional) The visibility of the image. Must be one of  "public", "private", "community", or "shared". The ability to set the  visibility depends upon the configuration of the OpenStack cloud.
    # "disk_format" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "visibility" - (Optional) The visibility of the image. Must be one of  "public", "private", "community", or "shared". The ability to set the  visibility depends upon the configuration of the OpenStack cloud.
    # "file" - the trailing path after the glance
    # "visibility" - (Optional) The visibility of the image. Must be one of  "public", "private", "community", or "shared". The ability to set the  visibility depends upon the configuration of the OpenStack cloud.
    # "id" - A unique ID assigned by Glance.
    # "visibility" - (Optional) The visibility of the image. Must be one of  "public", "private", "community", or "shared". The ability to set the  visibility depends upon the configuration of the OpenStack cloud.
    # "metadata" - The metadata associated with the image.
    # "visibility" - (Optional) The visibility of the image. Must be one of  "public", "private", "community", or "shared". The ability to set the  visibility depends upon the configuration of the OpenStack cloud.
    # "min_disk_gb" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "visibility" - (Optional) The visibility of the image. Must be one of  "public", "private", "community", or "shared". The ability to set the  visibility depends upon the configuration of the OpenStack cloud.
    # "min_ram_mb" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "visibility" - (Optional) The visibility of the image. Must be one of  "public", "private", "community", or "shared". The ability to set the  visibility depends upon the configuration of the OpenStack cloud.
    # "name" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "visibility" - (Optional) The visibility of the image. Must be one of  "public", "private", "community", or "shared". The ability to set the  visibility depends upon the configuration of the OpenStack cloud.
    # "owner" - The id of the openstack user who owns the image.
    # "visibility" - (Optional) The visibility of the image. Must be one of  "public", "private", "community", or "shared". The ability to set the  visibility depends upon the configuration of the OpenStack cloud.
    # "properties" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "visibility" - (Optional) The visibility of the image. Must be one of  "public", "private", "community", or "shared". The ability to set the  visibility depends upon the configuration of the OpenStack cloud.
    # "protected" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "visibility" - (Optional) The visibility of the image. Must be one of  "public", "private", "community", or "shared". The ability to set the  visibility depends upon the configuration of the OpenStack cloud.
    # "region" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "visibility" - (Optional) The visibility of the image. Must be one of  "public", "private", "community", or "shared". The ability to set the  visibility depends upon the configuration of the OpenStack cloud.
    # "schema" - The path to the JSON-schema that represent
    # "visibility" - (Optional) The visibility of the image. Must be one of  "public", "private", "community", or "shared". The ability to set the  visibility depends upon the configuration of the OpenStack cloud.
    # "size_bytes" - The size in bytes of the data associated with the image.
    # "visibility" - (Optional) The visibility of the image. Must be one of  "public", "private", "community", or "shared". The ability to set the  visibility depends upon the configuration of the OpenStack cloud.
    # "status" - The status of the image. It can be "queued", "active"
    # "visibility" - (Optional) The visibility of the image. Must be one of  "public", "private", "community", or "shared". The ability to set the  visibility depends upon the configuration of the OpenStack cloud.
    # "tags" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "visibility" - (Optional) The visibility of the image. Must be one of  "public", "private", "community", or "shared". The ability to set the  visibility depends upon the configuration of the OpenStack cloud.
    # "update_at" - The date the image was last updated.
    # "visibility" - (Optional) The visibility of the image. Must be one of  "public", "private", "community", or "shared". The ability to set the  visibility depends upon the configuration of the OpenStack cloud.
    # "visibility" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "visibility" - (Optional) The visibility of the image. Must be one of  "public", "private", "community", or "shared". The ability to set the  visibility depends upon the configuration of the OpenStack cloud.
}

openstack-resource-lb-listener-v2.body:
resource "openstack_lb_listener_v2" "$1" {
    # loadbalancer_id - (Required) The load balancer on which to provision this   Listener. Changing this creates a new Listener.
    loadbalancer_id = ""

    # protocol_port - (Required) The port on which to listen for client traffic.   Changing this creates a new Listener.
    protocol_port = ""

    # protocol - (Required) The protocol - can either be TCP, HTTP, HTTPS or TERMINATED_HTTPS.   Changing this creates a new Listener.
    protocol = ""

    # region - (Optional) The region in which to obtain the V2 Networking client.   A Networking client is needed to create an . If omitted, the   `region` argument of the provider is used. Changing this creates a new   Listener.
    region = ""

    # tenant_id - (Optional) Required for admins. The UUID of the tenant who owns   the Listener.  Only administrative users can specify a tenant UUID   other than their own. Changing this creates a new Listener.
    tenant_id = ""

    # name - (Optional) Human-readable name for the Listener. Does not have   to be unique.
    name = ""

    # default_pool_id - (Optional) The ID of the default pool with which the   Listener is associated. Changing this creates a new Listener.
    default_pool_id = ""

    # description - (Optional) Human-readable description for the Listener.
    description = ""

    # connection_limit - (Optional) The maximum number of connections allowed   for the Listener.
    connection_limit = ""

    # default_tls_container_ref - (Optional) A reference to a Barbican Secrets   container which stores TLS information. This is required if the protocol   is `TERMINATED_HTTPS`. See   [here](https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Network/LBaaS/docs/how-to-create-tls-loadbalancer)   for more information.
    default_tls_container_ref = ""

    # sni_container_refs - (Optional) A list of references to Barbican Secrets   containers which store SNI information. See   [here](https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Network/LBaaS/docs/how-to-create-tls-loadbalancer)   for more information.
    sni_container_refs = ""

    # admin_state_up - (Optional) The administrative state of the Listener.   A valid value is true (UP) or false (DOWN).
    admin_state_up = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "id" - The unique ID for the Listener.

    # "description" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "admin_state_up" - (Optional) The administrative state of the Listener.   A valid value is true (UP) or false (DOWN).
    # "connection_limit" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "admin_state_up" - (Optional) The administrative state of the Listener.   A valid value is true (UP) or false (DOWN).

    # region - (Optional) The region in which to obtain the V2 Networking client.   A Networking client is needed to create an LB member. If omitted, the   `region` argument of the provider is used. Changing this creates a new   LB member.
    region = ""

    # name - (Optional) Human-readable name for the Loadbalancer. Does not have   to be unique.
    name = ""

    # description - (Optional) Human-readable description for the Loadbalancer.
    description = ""

    # tenant_id - (Optional) Required for admins. The UUID of the tenant who owns   the Loadbalancer.  Only administrative users can specify a tenant UUID   other than their own.  Changing this creates a new loadbalancer.
    tenant_id = ""

    # vip_address - (Optional) The ip address of the load balancer.   Changing this creates a new loadbalancer.
    vip_address = ""

    # admin_state_up - (Optional) The administrative state of the Loadbalancer.   A valid value is true (UP) or false (DOWN).

    # flavor - (Optional) The UUID of a flavor. Changing this creates a new   loadbalancer.

    # "security_group_ids" - (Optional) A list of security group IDs to apply to the   loadbalancer. The security groups must be specified by ID and not name (as   opposed to how they are configured with the Compute Instance).
    # "vip_address" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "security_group_ids" - (Optional) A list of security group IDs to apply to the   loadbalancer. The security groups must be specified by ID and not name (as   opposed to how they are configured with the Compute Instance).
    # "admin_state_up" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "security_group_ids" - (Optional) A list of security group IDs to apply to the   loadbalancer. The security groups must be specified by ID and not name (as   opposed to how they are configured with the Compute Instance).
    # "flavor" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "security_group_ids" - (Optional) A list of security group IDs to apply to the   loadbalancer. The security groups must be specified by ID and not name (as   opposed to how they are configured with the Compute Instance).
    # "loadbalancer_provider" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "security_group_ids" - (Optional) A list of security group IDs to apply to the   loadbalancer. The security groups must be specified by ID and not name (as   opposed to how they are configured with the Compute Instance).
    # "security_group_ids" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "security_group_ids" - (Optional) A list of security group IDs to apply to the   loadbalancer. The security groups must be specified by ID and not name (as   opposed to how they are configured with the Compute Instance).
    # "vip_port_id" - The Port ID of the Load Balancer IP.

openstack-resource-lb-monitor-v1.body:
resource "openstack_lb_monitor_v1" "$1" {
    # max_retries - (Required) Number of permissible ping failures before changing   the member's status to INACTIVE. Must be a number between 1 and 10. Changing   this updates the max_retries of the existing monitor.
    max_retries = ""

    # timeout - (Required) Maximum number of seconds for a monitor to wait for a   ping reply before it times out. The value must be less than the delay value.   Changing this updates the timeout of the existing monitor.
    timeout = ""

    # delay - (Required) The time, in seconds, between sending probes to members.   Changing this creates a new monitor.
    delay = ""

    # type - (Required) The type of probe, which is PING, TCP, HTTP, or HTTPS,   that is sent by the monitor to verify the member state. Changing this   creates a new monitor.
    type = ""

    # region - (Optional) The region in which to obtain the V2 Networking client.   A Networking client is needed to create an LB monitor. If omitted, the   `region` argument of the provider is used. Changing this creates a new   LB monitor.
    region = ""

    # url_path - (Optional) Required for HTTP(S) types. URI path that will be   accessed if monitor type is HTTP or HTTPS. Changing this updates the   url_path of the existing monitor.
    url_path = ""

    # http_method - (Optional) Required for HTTP(S) types. The HTTP method used   for requests by the monitor. If this attribute is not specified, it defaults   to "GET". Changing this updates the http_method of the existing monitor.
    http_method = ""

    # expected_codes - (Optional) equired for HTTP(S) types. Expected HTTP codes   for a passing HTTP(S) monitor. You can either specify a single status like   "200", or a range like "200-202". Changing this updates the expected_codes   of the existing monitor.
    expected_codes = ""

    # admin_state_up - (Optional) The administrative state of the monitor.   Acceptable values are "true" and "false". Changing this value updates the   state of the existing monitor.
    admin_state_up = ""

    # tenant_id - (Optional) The owner of the monitor. Required if admin wants to   create a monitor for another tenant. Changing this creates a new monitor.
    tenant_id = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "region" - See Argument Reference above.

resource "openstack_networking_floatingip_v2" "$1" {
    # pool - (Required) The name of the pool from which to obtain the floating   IP. Changing this creates a new floating IP.
    pool = ""

    # region - (Optional) The region in which to obtain the V2 Networking client.   A Networking client is needed to create a floating IP that can be used with   another networking resource, such as a load balancer. If omitted, the   `region` argument of the provider is used. Changing this creates a new   floating IP (which may or may not have a different address).
    region = ""

    # port_id - (Optional) ID of an existing port with at least one IP address to   associate with this floating IP.
    port_id = ""

    # tenant_id - (Optional) The target tenant ID in which to allocate the floating   IP, if you specify this together with a port_id, make sure the target port   belongs to the same tenant. Changing this creates a new floating IP (which   may or may not have a different address)
    tenant_id = ""

    # fixed_ip - (Optional) Fixed IP of the port to associate with this floating IP. Required if the port has multiple fixed IPs.
    fixed_ip = ""

    # value_specs - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    value_specs = ""

    # Exported Attributes
    # "region" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    # "pool" - See Argument Reference above.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    # "address" - The actual floating IP address itself.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    # "port_id" - ID of associated port.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    # "tenant_id" - the ID of the tenant in which to create the floating IP.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.
    # "fixed_ip" - The fixed IP which the floating IP maps to.
    # "value_specs" - (Optional) Map of additional options.
}
openstack-resource-networking-floatingip.description:
Manages a V2 floating IP resource within OpenStack Neutron (networking)
that can be used for load balancers.
These are similar to Nova (compute) floating IP resources,
but only compute floating IPs can be used with compute instances.

    # region - (Optional) The region in which to obtain the V2 networking client.   A networking client is needed to create a router. If omitted, the   `region` argument of the provider is used. Changing this creates a new   router.
    region = ""

    # name - (Optional) A unique name for the router. Changing this   updates the `name` of an existing router.
    name = ""

    # admin_state_up - (Optional) Administrative up/down status for the router   (must be "true" or "false" if provided). Changing this updates the   `admin_state_up` of an existing router.
    admin_state_up = ""

    # distributed - (Optional) Indicates whether or not to create a   distributed router. The default policy setting in Neutron restricts   usage of this property to administrative users only.
    distributed = ""

    # external_gateway - (Optional) The network UUID of an external gateway for   the router. A router with an external gateway is required if any compute   instances or load balancers will be using floating IPs. Changing this   updates the `external_gateway` of an existing router.

    # enable_snat - (Optional) Enable Source NAT for the router.   (must be "true" or "false" if provided). An `external_gateway` has to be    set in order to set the `enable_snat` property. Changing this   updates the `enable_snat` of an existing router.

}

    next_hop = ""

    destination_cidr = ""

    end = ""

    start = ""

    # cidr - (Required) CIDR representing IP range for this subnet, based on IP   version. Changing this creates a new subnet.
    cidr = ""

    network_id = ""

    # region - (Optional) The region in which to obtain the V2 Networking client.   A Networking client is needed to create a Neutron subnet. If omitted, the   `region` argument of the provider is used. Changing this creates a new   subnet.
    region = ""

    # ip_version - (Optional) IP version, either 4 (default) or 6. Changing this creates a   new subnet.
    ip_version = ""

    # name - (Optional) The name of the subnet. Changing this updates the name of   the existing subnet.
    name = ""

    # tenant_id - (Optional) The owner of the subnet. Required if admin wants to   create a subnet for another tenant. Changing this creates a new subnet.
    tenant_id = ""

    # allocation_pools - (Optional) An array of sub-ranges of CIDR available for   dynamic allocation to ports. The allocation_pool object structure is   documented below. Changing this creates a new subnet.
    allocation_pools = ""

    # gateway_ip - (Optional)  Default gateway used by devices in this subnet.   Leaving this blank and not setting `no_gateway` will cause a default   gateway of `.1` to be used. Changing this updates the gateway IP of the   existing subnet.
    gateway_ip = ""

    # no_gateway - (Optional) Do not set a gateway IP on this subnet. Changing   this removes or adds a default gateway IP of the existing subnet.
    no_gateway = ""

    # enable_dhcp - (Optional) The administrative state of the network.   Acceptable values are "true" and "false". Changing this value enables or   disables the DHCP capabilities of the existing subnet. Defaults to true.
    enable_dhcp = ""

    # dns_nameservers - (Optional) An array of DNS name server names used by hosts   in this subnet. Changing this updates the DNS name servers for the existing   subnet.

    # host_routes - (Optional) An array of routes that should be used by devices   with IPs from this subnet (not including local subnet route). The host_route   object structure is documented below. Changing this updates the host routes   for the existing subnet.
    host_routes = ""
